title: Surgery, Scars & MG

content: This one is very special to me, and very personal.
If you have surgery scars, physical ones and emotional ones, this one’s for you too.
Before 2022, I never imagined myself hospitalized, let alone hearing the words “cancer,” “open-chest surgery,” or “chronic illness.” Not at 26 years old.
One day I was totally fine, and the next I was bedridden in the ICU. Everything went downhill so fast, I never had time to grasp what was happening or prepare for it.
I woke up Dec. 24 of that year with bandages covering my chest and stomach. I was in great pain.

A few weeks earlier, I was in a health crisis and received my myasthenia gravis (MG) diagnosis. As a precaution, a chest CT scan was done, and it revealed a tumor. After that, my life completely changed. I didn’t know what the outcome would be. I started seeing about half a dozen doctors daily, from different medical specialties.

I woke up Dec. 24 of that year with bandages covering my chest and stomach. I was in great pain.

A few weeks earlier, I was in a health crisis and received my myasthenia gravis (MG) diagnosis. As a precaution, a chest CT scan was done, and it revealed a tumor. After that, my life completely changed. I didn’t know what the outcome would be. I started seeing about half a dozen doctors daily, from different medical specialties.

content: The main goal of my ICU team was getting me out of the MG crisis. I underwent several treatments that helped ease my MG symptoms for a few hours, but they crawled back at night leaving me sleepless, hopeless, and unable to breathe.
The verdict was in. The tumor was fighting my immune system, despite the treatments. Surgery needed to happen, and quickly.
My thoracic surgeon showed me the scan results. They revealed, unfortunately, that my tumor was quite large. We aimed to remove it all, surgically.
In other words, a traditional sternotomy was my safest option for hopefully removing all of the tumor. The procedure is also known as open-chest surgery.

Instantly, my doctor apologized that I had to go through this. “You would be left with a permanent scar in the middle of your chest, where the incision will take place. I know that’s hard to hear, especially for a woman your age. … But after the surgery and your recovery, we can talk about your options.”

I remember how hard those words sounded in my ears. My chest area is obviously a very important part of my femininity, of my youth, of my future dream of becoming a mother. I wasn’t ready for that change. No one can be, I guess. But I had no choice.

content: The cancer was fighting hard, and I was fighting for my life.

The next morning, my surgeon said, “We’ll be ready to operate on you as soon as your other doctors say your state allows.” I looked up chest tattoo designs to cover my scar. I told myself it’s OK, we’ll cover it when it’s all over.

Fast-forward to February 2023. All of the tape, stitches, and bandages were removed from my body, revealing a big, thick, dark “zipper” scar as they call it, as well as several other scars marking where chest tubes were.
Everytime I looked in the mirror, tears streamed down my face.

I thought, I’ll never again see my chest the way it was. I already missed it. I thought about how I didn’t deserve this. It made me ache, on top of all the pain and other surprises life was throwing at me.
Scars can be extremely hard to accept. They’re a reality you can’t change. Many MG warriors and cancer survivors who have a thymectomyhave to go through this.

content: Three months post-op, when I started thoracic rehabilitation, my physiotherapist’s first words were, “Krystel, you have to touch your scars, stop being afraid. Familiarize yourself with them. They are a part of you now.”

As an exercise, and in order to help my nerves and fascia grow back under my sternum scar, my physiotherapist advised me to massage the area slowly. That helped my blood circulate better and heal faster.

My chest felt strange to me, ugly even. I looked up sternotomy scars. Some were much lighter than mine, and thinner.  Mine is called a “keloid scar,” which means it’s thicker than usual. And I have very sensitive skin, so my scar remains a bit red to this day.

My first summer post-op felt awkward and changed me in a lot of ways. My appearance was altered so much, due to steroid weight gain and scars. I was always self-conscious when I was out. (Steroids were one of my MG treatments)

content: I’d be out with my friends and people would stare at my red scar, which was still healing. I felt uncomfortable and embarrassed, and I wished it would just disappear.
On top of that, when it was hot and sunny, my sweat caused extreme itchiness on my scars. To sum up, it wasn’t my best summer.
I found articles (just like the ones I’m writing now!) about how to overcome scars and accept them. How to accept the changes that are irreversible in your body?
My surgeon recommended using vitamin E ointments because fancy, expensive products that claim to make scars disappear don’t help. Vitamin E helped my itchiness and eased the redness a little bit.
A friend recommended Bio-Oil, which helped lighten the color of my smaller chest-tube scars, but not my main zipper scar. This one remained intact, dividing my chest in two.
Nothing will ever make it disappear, and I’m OK with that now. As a matter of fact, I’ve come to love my scars.

content: As for my emotional scars, they’re also permanent. But it helps to look in the mirror every morning and be grateful I’m still here, and say beautiful positive things to start my day:

Today, when I look in the mirror, I’m so proud of the person looking back at me. She’s a beautiful, resilient, perfectly imperfect woman. If it weren’t for her strength and faith, I wouldn’t be where I am today. She went through so much and she’s still picking herself back up while fighting a chronic illness.

When I have kids, they may ask me, “Why do you have these things on your body unlike other women?” I’ll tell them I had to fight and win over cancer! They're my battle scars and I’ll always proudly show them off.
My four visible scars are a tattoo by themselves, tracing the story of how I survived. I don’t need to cover them. They shaped me into the woman I’ve become, and she is the strongest person I know.

content: That being said:
Here are MY TIPS FOR YOUR FIRST FEW MONTHS WITH SURGERY SCARS:

A lot of people have scars, and to each one their own journey.  Whether you had a mastectomy, open-chest surgery, brain surgery, or something else resulting in permanent scars, my heart goes out to you.  Be kind to yourself, you did your best!
bullets: Immediately consult with your surgeon or medical team if you feel any liquid from the incision.
Do not remove the compress by yourself after you’re discharged from the hospital. Your medical team should follow up with you and clean and monitor your scars until you’re fully healed.
Avoid direct sun for at least 6 months post-op. Always wear sunscreen on your scar to protect it.
Do not swim, soak in a hot tub, or take baths until your incision is completely healed.
Stay hydrated, especially in the summer. Dehydration might slow down your healing process.
Wear cotton fabric, especially if you have sensitive skin. Other fabrics worsened my itchiness.
Gently wash your scar when you shower. Avoid using fragrances or creams on it, at least until it fully heals.
